Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): කණඋල්ලා (Kanaulla), දුමුටු කණඋල්ලා (Dumutu Kanaulla) / Sirupaambu (சிறு பாம்பு)
A detailed description: A very small, thin, worm-like snake, typically 10-15 cm long. The body is uniformly covered in tiny, glossy, overlapping scales of dark brown, greyish-black, or purplish color. The head is indistinct from the neck, and the eyes are reduced to tiny, barely visible dark spots. The tail is short and blunt, ending in a tiny, harmless spur.
how to find(recognize): Often mistaken for an earthworm. Differentiated from worms by its glossy scales, rapid, non-undulating movement, and a dry, non-slimy body. It cannot retract or expand its body like an earthworm. Found under loose soil, in flowerpots, under decaying logs, stones, and leaf litter. Often surfaces after heavy rain.
foods they eat: Primarily feeds on the eggs, larvae, and pupae of ants and termites.
Contagion (Reproduction): Parthenogenetic (all-female species). Reproduction occurs without males. It lays 2-8 tiny, elongated eggs which hatch into miniature versions of the adult.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread throughout the island, from coastal lowlands up to mid-hills (around 1500m).

Common English Name(s): Sri Lanka Worm Snake, Ceylonese Blind Snake
A detailed description: A small, rare, fossorial (burrowing) snake with a slender, cylindrical body. It has a shiny, smooth-scaled appearance. The head is not distinct from the body. Eyes are vestigial, appearing as dark spots beneath translucent scales. Detailed descriptions of coloration and scalation are scarce.
how to find(recognize): Extremely rare and difficult to find. It is a burrowing species, likely inhabiting loose soil and leaf litter in forested areas of the wet zone. Identification requires expert examination of head scales to differentiate it from other blind snakes.
foods they eat: Diet is not specifically documented but is presumed to be similar to other blind snakes, consisting of small invertebrates like ant and termite larvae.
Contagion (Reproduction): Oviparous (egg-laying). Specific details on clutch size and breeding habits are not well-documented due to its rarity.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known from the wet zone, particularly in the central hills. The type specimen was from Peradeniya. Records are scarce, suggesting a very restricted distribution.

A detailed description: This species is found in Southeast Asia (e.g., Thailand, Malaysia) and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

A detailed description: This species is found in Myanmar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

A detailed description: This species is found in the Philippines and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

A detailed description: This species is found in Southern India and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

A detailed description: This genus is endemic to Madagascar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This genus is endemic to Madagascar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This genus is endemic to Madagascar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This genus is endemic to Madagascar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This genus is endemic to Madagascar and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Common English Name(s): Sri Lankan Pipe Snake, Ceylonese Cylinder Snake
A detailed description: A small to medium-sized snake (up to 75 cm) with a cylindrical body and short, blunt tail that resembles the head. The dorsal coloration consists of a black or dark brown background with two series of large, irregular reddish-brown or orange blotches. The belly is distinctively patterned with alternating large black and white squares or bands.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its unique 'two-headed' appearance (blunt head and tail) and striking black-and-white checkered belly. When threatened, it hides its head and raises its tail, flattening it to display the bright underside, mimicking a cobra's hood. It's a burrowing snake, found under loose soil, leaf litter, and rotting logs.
foods they eat: Specialized diet consisting of other snakes (especially blind snakes and shieldtails), eels, and caecilians. May also eat earthworms.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young). Produces litters of 2-15 young.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the low country wet and intermediate zones, and mid-hills up to about 1000m. Common in agricultural areas like paddy fields and home gardens.

A detailed description: While some older records exist, modern checklists consider the genus Platyplectrurus to be endemic to the Western Ghats of India. Its presence in Sri Lanka is not currently accepted by most herpetologists.
how to find(recognize): Its presence in Sri Lanka is not currently accepted by most herpetologists.
foods they eat: Its presence in Sri Lanka is not currently accepted by most herpetologists.
Contagion (Reproduction): Its presence in Sri Lanka is not currently accepted by most herpetologists.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Its presence in Sri Lanka is not currently accepted by most herpetologists.

A detailed description: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): බ්ලයිත්ගේ තේරිවාලා (Blythge Theriwala), දත් තේරිවාලා (Dath Theriwala)
A detailed description: A small burrowing snake with a pointed snout and a large, flattened tail shield. The body is dark brown or blackish above, often with yellow spots or crossbars. The belly is yellowish, mottled with dark brown. The tail shield is large and covered with keeled scales.
how to find(recognize): Identified by its pointed head for burrowing and a distinctive, large, rough tail shield. It's a fossorial species, found in loose soil, under rocks, and in decaying vegetation in montane and sub-montane forests.
foods they eat: Feeds primarily on earthworms.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young), producing 2-5 offspring.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Central hills of Sri Lanka, typically above 900m elevation. Found in areas like Nuwara Eliya, Horton Plains, and Hakgala.

A detailed description: A small, slender shieldtail snake. Dorsal color is uniform iridescent black or dark brown. The ventral side is dark with some lighter mottling. The tail ends in a small, convex, and smooth shield. Total length around 25 cm.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from other Rhinophis by its smooth, small tail shield and mostly uniform dark coloration. A rare, burrowing species found in soil and leaf litter of montane forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms and other soft-bodied invertebrates.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known from the central highlands, specifically from areas like Pattipola and Ohiya.

A detailed description: A relatively large shieldtail (up to 40 cm). The dorsal side is dark purplish-brown. It has a distinctive series of bright yellow triangular spots along each side of the body, and a yellow band across the tail shield. The belly is brownish. The tail shield is large and covered in coarse keels.
how to find(recognize): Easily recognized by the prominent row of yellow triangular markings along its flanks. A fossorial snake found in wet forests, plantations (tea, cardamom), and home gardens in the central hills.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Central hills, primarily in the Uva Province, in areas like Gannoruwa, Gammaduwa, and the Knuckles mountain range.

A detailed description: A small species, uniformly brown or blackish-brown on the dorsal side. The ventral side is slightly lighter. The key feature is the tail shield, which is distinctly flattened and concave (depressed in the middle).
how to find(recognize): Identified by its unique concave tail shield, a feature not seen in other Sri Lankan Rhinophis. It is a burrowing snake, found in soil and under decaying logs in montane forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from a very restricted area in the Morningside forest reserve, within the Sinharaja World Heritage Site.

A detailed description: A small, slender shieldtail. The back is uniformly iridescent dark brown. It has a distinct thin yellow line running along the lower part of its sides, from the snout to the tail. The tail shield is small and weakly keeled.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by the continuous yellow lateral stripe on a dark body. It is a fossorial species inhabiting leaf litter and loose soil in rainforest habitats.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from the southern edge of the Sinharaja rainforest.

A detailed description: Dorsal color is dark brown or black with numerous small yellow spots, sometimes forming irregular crossbars. The ventral side is brown, mottled with yellow. Tail shield is large and covered with spiny keels.
how to find(recognize): Identified by its dark body covered in many small yellow spots, giving it a speckled appearance. Found in the soil and leaf litter of lowland rainforests and nearby plantations.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the lowland wet zone, including areas like Kandy, Peradeniya, and the Sinharaja region.

A detailed description: A very small and slender shieldtail. It is uniquely colored with a bright yellow dorsal stripe running from the head to the tail, bordered by dark brown or black sides. The belly is white. The tail shield is small and smooth.
how to find(recognize): Unmistakable due to the prominent, single yellow stripe down its back. It's a burrowing snake, found in humus and loose soil in lowland rainforests.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms and other small, soft-bodied invertebrates.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Extremely rare, known only from a few specimens from a very small area in the lowland wet zone (e.g., Gampola).

A detailed description: One of the largest shieldtails (up to 50 cm). The body is yellowish-brown or greyish above, with each scale having a darker brown spot, forming faint longitudinal lines. The snout is sharply pointed. The tail shield is large and strongly keeled.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its larger size, sharply pointed snout, and drab, earthy coloration. It is a powerful burrower found in sandy soils in the dry and intermediate zones, often in scrubland and agricultural areas.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the low country dry and intermediate zones, from the northern plains down to the south-eastern coast.

A detailed description: A slender shieldtail with a dark brown or black back. It is distinguished by a series of separate, large, bright yellow blotches along its lower sides. The belly is dark. The tail shield is large and strongly keeled.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from R. drummondhayi by having separate yellow blotches on the sides, rather than connected triangular spots. A burrowing species found in wet montane forests and tea estates.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Central hills, in areas like Gammaduwa and the Knuckles mountain range.

A detailed description: A medium-sized shieldtail. Dorsal coloration is light brown or yellowish with three prominent series of large, round, dark brown or black spots running down the body. The belly is yellowish. The tail shield is flattened and covered with coarse keels.
how to find(recognize): Easily identified by the three rows of large, distinct dark spots on a lighter background. Fossorial, found in loose soil and humus in lowland and sub-montane wet zone forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the wet zone, from lowlands to mid-hills, in locations like Kandy, Labugama, and parts of the Sinharaja region.

A detailed description: The largest shieldtail species in Sri Lanka (can exceed 50 cm). It has a robust body, dark brown to black above, with an iridescent sheen. The belly is dark. The tail shield is very large, circular, and covered with coarse, spiny keels.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its large size, robust build, uniform dark color, and very large, rough tail shield. A powerful burrower found in the soil of lowland rainforests and adjacent plantations.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Lowland wet zone, particularly in the Sabaragamuwa Province, including areas like Ratnapura and the Sinharaja forest.

A detailed description: Despite the name 'ceylanicus', this species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is not found in Sri Lanka. The name is a historical misnomer.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: This is a synonym of Rhinophis saffragamus (Kelaart
A detailed description: a species already listed. It is not a distinct species.
how to find(recognize): (Synonym)
foods they eat: See entry for Rhinophis saffragamus.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: See entry for Rhinophis saffragamus.

A detailed description: A very small and rare shieldtail. Body is uniformly black or dark brown with a strong iridescent sheen. Unlike Rhinophis, the tail does not end in a large shield but is truncated obliquely, ending in a somewhat flattened, rough surface.
how to find(recognize): Identified as a Uropeltis by its obliquely truncated tail (not a large shield). It is extremely rare and fossorial, inhabiting deep soil and leaf litter in specific lowland rainforest patches.
foods they eat: Feeds on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from a few specific locations in the southern lowland wet zone, such as the Kottawa and Dellawa forests.

A detailed description: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Non-venomous, Harmless to humans but can deliver a painful bite. Not medically significant.
Global IUCN Red List Status: VU (Vulnerable) (globally, the subspecies in Sri Lanka, P. m. pimbura, is considered vulnerable)
A detailed description: A very large, heavy-bodied snake, commonly reaching 3-4 meters. The body is patterned with large, irregular, dark brown blotches on a lighter yellowish or tan background. It has a distinctive arrowhead-shaped marking on its head and heat-sensing pits along the upper lip.
how to find(recognize): Unmistakable due to its large size, robust build, and python pattern. It is semi-arboreal when young but mostly terrestrial as an adult. Found in a variety of habitats including forests, scrublands, grasslands, and near water bodies. Often found in rocky outcrops and abandoned burrows.
foods they eat: Feeds on a wide range of mammals (from rodents to deer fawns and monkeys) and birds. It is a non-venomous constrictor, killing prey by suffocation.
Contagion (Reproduction): Oviparous (egg-laying). The female lays a large clutch of up to 100 eggs and coils around them to provide warmth through muscular shivering (thermoregulation) until they hatch.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the island, from the low country dry zone to the wet zone and lower hills, but is becoming increasingly uncommon due to habitat loss and persecution.

Common English Name(s): Rough-scaled Sand Boa, Common Sand Boa
Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): වැලි පිඹුරා (Weli Pimbura) / Mann Pambu (மண் பாம்பு)
A detailed description: A short, stout-bodied snake with a very blunt tail, typically under 60 cm. The scales are heavily keeled, giving it a rough texture. Coloration is a mix of yellowish, brown, and grey, with dark brown or black irregular blotches. The head is wedge-shaped and not distinct from the neck.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its thick, stumpy body, rough scales, and very short, blunt tail. It is a burrowing snake, often found in sandy or loose soil in arid and semi-arid regions. It lies buried with just its eyes and snout exposed, waiting to ambush prey.
foods they eat: Feeds primarily on small rodents (mice, rats), which it ambushes from below the sand. It also eats small lizards and birds. Kills prey by constriction.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young), producing litters of 1-14 offspring.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Primarily found in the coastal areas of the dry zone, especially in the north, northwest (Puttalam, Mannar), and southeast (Yala, Bundala).

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): මුහුදු දිය ගොයා (Mudu Diya Goya), රිවෝල් සර්පයා (Rivol Sarpaya)
A detailed description: A fully aquatic snake with a unique, baggy skin covered in tiny, granular, keeled scales that give it a rough, file-like texture. It has a flattened, paddle-like tail. Coloration is grey or brown with pale crossbands. It cannot move effectively on land.
how to find(recognize): Instantly recognizable by its loose, baggy skin and sandpaper-like texture. It is found in coastal marine waters, estuaries, and river mouths. Often caught in fishing nets.
foods they eat: Feeds almost exclusively on small fish and crustaceans, such as gobies and crabs.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young), producing small litters of 1-12 young directly in the water.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in coastal waters and estuaries around the island.

Common English Name(s): Common Vine Snake, Green Vine Snake
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Venom is not considered dangerous to humans, but a bite can cause localized swelling and pain. Not medically significant.
A detailed description: extremely slender snake with a sharply pointed snout. The body is bright leaf-green above and pale green or yellowish below. It has binocular vision
how to find(recognize): with horizontal
foods they eat: keyhole-shaped pupils. Can grow up to 1.5 meters."
Contagion (Reproduction): Identified by its pencil-thin body, vibrant green color, and long, pointed head. It is an arboreal (tree-dwelling) snake, perfectly camouflaged among foliage in gardens, forests, and plantations. When threatened, it inflates its neck to display black and white interstitial skin.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds mainly on lizards (especially geckos and agamids), frogs, and occasionally small birds and rodents.

Common English Name(s): Brown-speckled Vine Snake, Brown Vine Snake
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Similar to A. nasuta, not considered dangerous to humans.
Global IUCN Red List Status: NT (Near Threatened),Similar in build to the Green Vine Snake but with different coloration. It is brownish or grayish
A detailed description: heavily speckled with black and white. The head is long and pointed. When threatened
how to find(recognize): it inflates its neck revealing a striking checkered pattern."
foods they eat: Distinguished from the common vine snake by its brown, speckled coloration. It is also an arboreal snake but is much rarer and prefers undisturbed forest habitats, especially in the wet zone.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on lizards, frogs, and other small arboreal animals.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young).

Global IUCN Red List Status: NE (Not Evaluated),This species is considered endemic to the Western Ghats of India. Older records from Sri Lanka are now considered misidentifications of other Ahaetulla species."
A detailed description: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): අළු හබරාලා (Alu Habarala) / Nikitan Pambu (நிகிதன் பாம்பு)
A detailed description: A small to medium-sized snake, typically olive-brown or greyish. It has two distinct buff, yellow, or orange stripes running along the length of its body on the lower flanks. The scales are keeled (ridged). When agitated, it flattens its neck to display bright blue or red coloration between the scales.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by the two light-colored stripes on its flanks and keeled scales. It is a terrestrial, diurnal snake found in open areas with grass and vegetation, especially near water, such as paddy fields, marshes, and grasslands.
foods they eat: Feeds primarily on frogs and toads, but will also eat fish, tadpoles, and insects.
Contagion (Reproduction): Oviparous (egg-laying), laying clutches of 5-15 eggs in moist soil or vegetation.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread and common throughout the island in all climatic zones up to about 1000m.

A detailed description: A small, fossorial snake with a brown or reddish-brown body. It has a series of small, blackish spots or a vertebral stripe. The belly is yellowish or orange. The tail is short and pointed. Scales are smooth.
how to find(recognize): This is the only Aspidura species found in the low country wet zone. It's a small, burrowing snake found under loose soil, rocks, and decaying logs in rainforests and well-wooded home gardens.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Confined to the lowland wet zone, from near sea level up to about 500m.

A detailed description: A small snake, yellowish-brown to dark brown above, with a prominent black vertebral stripe that runs the entire length of the body. The belly is yellow or orange.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished by the single, continuous black line running down its back. A high-altitude, burrowing snake found in montane forests, tea estates, and home gardens under rocks and logs.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the central highlands, typically above 1200m, in areas like Nuwara Eliya, Horton Plains, and Pattipola.

A detailed description: A medium-sized Aspidura. The body is dark brown or black above, with a striking bright yellow or orange collar just behind the head. The belly is checkered with black and yellow/orange.
how to find(recognize): Unmistakable due to the bright yellow/orange nuchal collar on a dark body. It is a burrowing snake found in the soil and leaf litter of montane and sub-montane forests.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Central hills, typically between 600m and 1800m. Found in areas like Kandy, Peradeniya, and the Knuckles range.

A detailed description: A small, slender species. Brown above with a faint, darker vertebral line. The belly is bright orange or red. It has a distinctively long tail for the genus.
how to find(recognize): Identified by its slender build, long tail, and bright red/orange belly. A very rare and localized species, found burrowing in the humus layer of specific rainforest habitats.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from a few locations in the Rakwana hills, such as the Morningside forest reserve.

A detailed description: A small species, light brown dorsally with a dark brown head. Lacks a vertebral stripe but has two rows of faint dark spots. The belly is bright reddish-orange.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished by its light brown color, dark head, and reddish-orange belly. A fossorial snake endemic to the Knuckles mountain range, found in soil under forest cover.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from the Knuckles Conservation Forest.

A detailed description: A stout-bodied Aspidura, dark brown or black above. It lacks a vertebral stripe but has irregular, small yellow spots or flecks, especially on the sides. The belly is black.
how to find(recognize): Identified by its robust build, dark coloration with yellow flecks, and solid black belly. A high-altitude species, found burrowing in montane forests and grasslands.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Endemic to the highest elevations of the central highlands, such as Horton Plains National Park.

A detailed description: A small, slender snake. Dark purplish-brown above with a faint, darker vertebral line. The belly is bright coral-red. The underside of the tail is black.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished by its slender body and bright red belly contrasted with a black subcaudal (under-tail) area. A burrowing species found in wet zone forests at mid-elevations.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the central hills around Kandy and the Sabaragamuwa province.

A detailed description: A small, dark brown snake with an iridescent sheen. It has a prominent, continuous yellow vertebral stripe. The belly is bright orange-red.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished by the combination of a yellow vertebral stripe and a bright orange-red belly. A burrowing species found in the soil and leaf litter of montane forests.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from a small area in the central highlands of the Uva province.

A detailed description: A common and variable species. Usually dark brown or black above, sometimes with faint spots or lines. The belly is typically yellow or orange, often with black spots or edges. The tail is short and thick.
how to find(recognize): The most common Aspidura species in the central hills. Differentiated from others by a combination of location and variable markings, often lacking the very distinct patterns of rarer species. Found in a wide range of habitats including forests, tea estates, and home gardens.
foods they eat: Feeds exclusively on earthworms.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread in the central highlands, between 1000m and 2000m.

A detailed description: A medium-sized, semi-aquatic snake. The body is typically uniform olive-green or brownish-green above, with a bright yellow, orange, or reddish belly. The scales are strongly keeled. The head is slightly wider than the neck.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its uniform olive color, bright belly, and keeled scales. It is always found in or near water, in ponds, streams, paddy fields, and marshes. It is an excellent swimmer.
foods they eat: Feeds on frogs, tadpoles, fish, and crabs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Common in the low country, especially in the dry and intermediate zones where slow-moving water bodies are abundant.

Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered medically significant, but caution is advised.
A detailed description: medium-sized snake. The body is olive-brown above with a series of yellow or greenish spots along the back. The most striking feature is its head and neck
how to find(recognize): which are bright green above and yellow on the lips. The belly is pale with black spots. Scales are keeled."
foods they eat: Unmistakable due to the bright green head and neck. It is a semi-aquatic and terrestrial snake, found along clear, fast-flowing streams and rivers in dense montane forests.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on frogs, fish, and lizards.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying).

Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). A bite can cause significant local pain and swelling but is not life-threatening.
A detailed description: slender
how to find(recognize): arboreal snake. Coloration is light brown or greyish-brown with a series of dark brown
foods they eat: inverted 'Y' shaped markings along the back. The head is large and distinct from the thin neck
Contagion (Reproduction): with large eyes and vertical pupils."
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Identified by the distinct 'Y' shaped markings on its back. It is a nocturnal, tree-dwelling snake found in wet zone forests, from lowlands to the hills.

Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered dangerous to humans.
A detailed description: arboreal snake. Light brown or greyish with faint
how to find(recognize): darker crossbars. The head is elongated. It lacks the prominent patterns of other Boiga species in Sri Lanka."
foods they eat: Recognized by its very slender build and relatively plain, light brown coloration compared to other cat snakes. A rare, nocturnal, and arboreal snake of wet zone forests.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying).

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): ලංකා මාපිලා (Lanka Mapila), නිදි මාපිලා (Nidi Mapila)
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Can deliver a painful bite with localized swelling. Not life-threatening.
A detailed description: arboreal snake with a laterally compressed body. Coloration is variable
how to find(recognize): usually light brown or greyish with a series of dark brown or blackish 'X' or 'H' shaped blotches along the back. Head is large with large eyes."
foods they eat: The most common cat snake in Sri Lanka. Identified by its size, arboreal nature, and the series of dark blotches along its back. It is nocturnal and often found in trees and shrubs in forests, plantations, and home gardens.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on lizards, birds, eggs, and small mammals.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying), laying 5-15 eggs.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): පොල් මල් කරවලා (Pol Mal Karawala), ලේ මාපිලා (Le Mapila)
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). It is a large snake and a bite can be very painful with significant swelling and blistering. Medical attention may be required, but it is not fatal.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A large and robust cat snake. Coloration is highly variable
A detailed description: but commonly reddish-brown or dark brown with bold black and white crossbars or blotches
how to find(recognize): especially on the anterior part of the body. The head is very large and distinct from the neck."
foods they eat: Recognized by its large size and bold, often colorful patterning. It is a powerful, nocturnal, and arboreal snake. Prefers forested areas but can be found in agricultural land.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on birds, eggs, bats, and other small mammals. It is known to raid chicken coops.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying).

Common English Name(s): Common Cat Snake, Indian Gamma Snake
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered dangerous to humans.
A detailed description: slender cat snake. Light brown or fawn colored with a series of dark-edged
how to find(recognize): Y-shaped white markings along the spine. It has a distinct dark marking on the head that resembles the Greek letter gamma. It often mimics the highly venomous Saw-scaled Viper."
foods they eat: Identified by the series of whitish Y-shaped markings along its back. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial, and semi-arboreal snake. Found in dry and arid scrublands.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds almost exclusively on lizards and geckos.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying).

A detailed description: A beautiful, medium-sized snake. The body is glossy black or dark purplish-brown, encircled by 20-30 distinct, narrow white or yellowish rings that are complete across the belly. The scales are strongly keeled.
how to find(recognize): Unmistakable due to its glossy black color with complete white rings and heavily keeled scales. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial snake. When threatened, it hides its head and raises its tail, which is thought to mimic the venomous krait. Found in leaf litter in wet zone forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards, skinks, and other snakes.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the lowland wet zone and mid-hills, up to about 1000m.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): මල් සරයා (Mal Saraya), පොල් මල් සරයා (Pol Mal Saraya)
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered dangerous to humans.
A detailed description: slender snake. The body is greenish-yellow with black crossbars. Each scale is black-edged and has a central yellow or green spot. The head has black and yellow stripes. It is capable of gliding flight."
how to find(recognize): Identified by its striking green and black pattern and its ability to glide. To glide, it flattens its body into a concave 'C' shape and launches from a high point, covering significant horizontal distances. It is a diurnal, arboreal snake found in forests, plantations, and home gardens.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards, geckos, frogs, birds, and bats, which it can sometimes catch in mid-air.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the low country, in both wet and dry zones.

Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered dangerous to humans.
Global IUCN Red List Status: VU (Vulnerable),Similar in build to C. ornata but with a different color pattern. The body is greyish-brown or olive-brown with orange or reddish spots along the back
A detailed description: each enclosed by a black ring. The belly is pale. It is also capable of gliding."
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from C. ornata by its brownish base color and orange/red dorsal spots. It is a diurnal, arboreal snake, but much rarer than its relative. It is primarily found in the dry and intermediate zones, often in taller trees.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards, geckos, and other small arboreal animals.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the low country dry and intermediate zones.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): කටකළුවා (Katakaluwa) (Note: This name is also used for Cercaspis carinata) / Kattu Pambu (கட்டு பாம்பு)
Venom & Medical Significance: Non-venomous, Harmless. It is a very nervous snake and will strike readily if threatened, but the bite is harmless.
A detailed description: slender snake. The body is light brown or olive-brown. The anterior part of the body has distinct
how to find(recognize): broad
foods they eat: black crossbands enclosing white or yellow ocelli (eyespots). The posterior body has two dark stripes. It has a distinctive black streak below the eye."
Contagion (Reproduction): Recognized by the ornate 'trinket' pattern of black and white ocelli on the front half of its body. It is a terrestrial, diurnal snake found in a variety of habitats, including scrubland, agricultural areas, and open forests. When threatened, it assumes a characteristic 'S' pose and inflates its neck.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds primarily on rodents, but also takes lizards and frogs.

A detailed description: A slender, arboreal snake. The body is bronze-brown above. It has a prominent black stripe that runs from the snout, through the eye, and along the entire length of the body. Below this is a creamy-yellow stripe. The belly is pale.
how to find(recognize): Identified by the distinct black stripe running the full length of its body, separating the bronze back from the cream flank stripe. It is a diurnal, tree-dwelling snake found in wet zone forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the lowland wet zone and the central hills.

A detailed description: A slender, arboreal snake. Bronze-brown above. It is distinguished by several thin, black lines on the posterior part of the body and on the tail. It also has a black stripe through the eye, but this stripe does not extend far down the body.
how to find(recognize): Identified by the presence of multiple fine black lines on the rear of its body and tail. It is a fast-moving, diurnal, and arboreal snake found in forests and well-wooded areas.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the island in all climatic zones.

A detailed description: A slender, arboreal snake. Bronze above. It is distinguished by having a broad, black band on the side of its neck, which then breaks up into oblique bars. It lacks a prominent stripe running down the body.
how to find(recognize): The key identifying feature is the broad black patch on the side of the neck. It is a diurnal, arboreal snake found in the forests of the central hills.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the central hills, typically at mid-to-high elevations.

A detailed description: This species is now considered a synonym of Dendrelaphis tristis. The name is no longer valid.
how to find(recognize): See entry for Dendrelaphis tristis.
foods they eat: See entry for Dendrelaphis tristis.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: See entry for Dendrelaphis tristis.

A detailed description: A slender, arboreal snake. Olive-brown dorsally. It has a broad black post-ocular stripe that extends to the neck. The key feature is the bright turquoise-blue coloration on the skin between the scales on the neck, which is displayed when agitated.
how to find(recognize): Identified by the brilliant blue interstitial skin on the neck region. It is a diurnal, arboreal snake confined to the Sinharaja rainforest.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known only from the Sinharaja World Heritage Site.

A detailed description: A very common, slender, arboreal snake. Bronze-brown or coppery above, with a pale underside. It has a faint black stripe through the eye that fades on the neck. When agitated, it may display bluish skin between the scales. It is extremely fast-moving.
how to find(recognize): The most common bronzeback. It is often identified by the absence of the very distinct patterns seen in other species. It is diurnal and highly active, found in a wide variety of habitats from forests to urban gardens.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards, geckos, frogs, and insects.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread and very common throughout the entire island.

A detailed description: A slender, arboreal snake. Distinguished by a combination of scale counts and a unique coloration: olive-green on the anterior half of the body, transitioning to a bronze-brown on the posterior half. It has a black stripe through the eye.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by the two-tone color pattern (green front, brown back). It is a diurnal, arboreal snake found in the lowland wet zone rainforests.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the lowland wet zone, including the Sinharaja region.

A detailed description: A small, slender, nocturnal snake. It has a dark brown or black body with thin, white or yellowish crossbands that are wider on the sides and narrow or interrupted at the spine. The head is broad and the snout is blunt.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from other bridle snakes by subtle differences in pattern and scale counts. It is a rare, arboreal snake found in lowland rainforests.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards, geckos, and their eggs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Known from the lowland wet zone forests.

A detailed description: A small, slender snake. The body is glossy dark brown or black with 40-50 thin, white or yellowish crossbands that bifurcate (split into a 'Y' shape) on the flanks. The belly is white. The head is broad with a blunt snout.
how to find(recognize): Identified by the thin white bands that split on the sides. It is a nocturnal, arboreal snake, often found in trees and shrubs, and sometimes entering houses in search of geckos. Found in a variety of habitats.
foods they eat: Feeds primarily on geckos and their eggs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Common throughout the low country, especially in the dry zone.

Common English Name(s): Sri Lankan Keelback, Checkered Keelback (local subspecies)
A detailed description: A medium-sized, stout-bodied, aquatic snake. The body is olive-brown or yellowish with a distinct checkerboard pattern of black spots. The belly is creamy white. The scales are heavily keeled.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its checkered pattern and aquatic habits. Often mistaken for the highly venomous Russell's Viper (Daboia russelii, 'Thith Polanga'), but the Keelback has keeled scales, a less distinct head, and is always found near water.
foods they eat: Feeds on frogs, fish, and rodents.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread and very common in and around freshwater bodies (ponds, lakes, paddy fields) throughout the island.

A detailed description: The species found in Sri Lanka, previously considered a subspecies of F. piscator, is now recognized as a distinct endemic species, Fowlea asperrimus. Therefore, F. piscator is not found in Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): See entry for Fowlea asperrimus.
foods they eat: See entry for Fowlea asperrimus.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: See entry for Fowlea asperrimus.

Common English Name(s): Gerard's Water Snake, Glossy Marsh Snake
Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Not considered dangerous to humans.
A detailed description: semi-aquatic snake. The body is uniform glossy grey
how to find(recognize): brown
foods they eat: or black above
Contagion (Reproduction): with a whitish or yellowish belly. The scales are smooth. It has adaptations for an aquatic life
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: including upward-facing nostrils."

A detailed description: A very small, thin snake. The body is light brown or greyish-brown above, with a faint darker vertebral line and some scattered black spots. The belly is whitish. The scales are smooth.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its very small size, slender build, and smooth scales. It is a secretive, terrestrial snake, found hiding in leaf litter, under stones, and in grass tussocks in a variety of habitats.
foods they eat: Feeds on small insects, spiders, and their eggs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the island in both wet and dry zones.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): අළු රදනකයා (Alu Radanakaya) / Veetukuthi Pambu (வீட்டுக்குத்தி பாம்பு)
Venom & Medical Significance: Non-venomous, Harmless. Mimics the venomous Common Krait. Bites readily but is not dangerous.
A detailed description: slender snake. Coloration is variable
how to find(recognize): typically brown or greyish-brown with a pattern of white or yellowish crossbands or a reticulated pattern. The belly is white. It has enlarged front teeth in the upper jaw
foods they eat: resembling fangs."
Contagion (Reproduction): Often confused with the highly venomous Common Krait (Bungarus caeruleus). The Wolf Snake's bands are usually lighter (white/yellow vs. brilliant white), and it has a more distinct head. It is a nocturnal snake, often found in and around human dwellings, climbing walls in search of geckos.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds primarily on geckos and other lizards.

A detailed description: Similar to L. aulicus, but generally has a more robust build and a different pattern. The body is dark brown with broad, distinct, bright yellow crossbands.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from the Common Wolf Snake by its bolder pattern of bright yellow bands. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial snake primarily found in forested areas.
foods they eat: Feeds on lizards and skinks.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the low country dry and intermediate zones.

Common English Name(s): Shaw's Wolf Snake, Barred Wolf Snake
A detailed description: A small snake, dark brown or black above with a series of narrow white or yellowish crossbars. These bars are more prominent on the anterior part of the body and may fade towards the tail. The belly is white.
how to find(recognize): Identified by its pattern of thin white/yellow bars on a dark background. It is a nocturnal, ground-dwelling snake found under rocks, logs, and debris in a variety of habitats, especially in the dry zone.
foods they eat: Feeds on skinks and other small lizards.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread throughout the island, particularly in the dry and intermediate zones.

Common English Name(s): Sri Lanka Wolf Snake (alternative name for Cercaspis carinata)
Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): This is an older name combination. The currently accepted scientific name for the Sri Lanka Wolf Snake with keeled scales is Cercaspis carinata.
A detailed description: See entry for Cercaspis carinata.
how to find(recognize): See entry for Cercaspis carinata.
foods they eat: See entry for Cercaspis carinata.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: See entry for Cercaspis carinata.

Common English Name(s): Common Kukri Snake, Banded Kukri Snake
Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): දත් කැටියා (Dath Kaetiya) / Ennai Pambu (எண்ணெய் பாம்பு)
Venom & Medical Significance: Non-venomous, Harmless. Has enlarged, blade-like rear teeth that can inflict a deep, bleeding cut if handled, but it is not venomous.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A small to medium-sized snake with smooth scales. The body is light brown or reddish-brown with 20-30 distinct
A detailed description: sharp-edged black crossbands. The head has a distinctive symmetrical pattern of three black chevrons or arrowheads. The belly is white."
how to find(recognize): Easily identified by the bold black bands and the arrowhead markings on its head. It is a terrestrial and burrowing snake, active during the day and at dusk. Found in a wide variety of habitats.
foods they eat: Feeds primarily on the eggs of reptiles and birds. It also eats lizards, frogs, and rodents. Its specialized teeth are used to slice open leathery eggs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread and common throughout the island, especially in the low country.

A detailed description: A very small kukri snake. The body is reddish-brown with a series of small, black, paired spots along the back. It has a yellow or orange collar behind the head. The belly is white with square black spots.
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its small size, paired black spots on the back, and a bright nuchal collar. It is a secretive, burrowing snake found in the leaf litter of wet zone forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on the eggs of small reptiles and insects.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the lowland wet zone and mid-hills.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): යට ඉරි දත් කැටියා (Yata Iri Dath Kaetiya)
A detailed description: A small kukri snake. The body is brown above, with a vertebral series of small, dark, diamond-shaped spots. The belly is distinctively marked with a black and white or pinkish checkerboard pattern. It may have a faint collar.
how to find(recognize): The key identifying feature is the black-and-white checkered belly. It is a terrestrial, semi-fossorial snake found in a variety of habitats, including forests, plantations, and home gardens.
foods they eat: Feeds on reptile eggs, insects, and small frogs.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Widespread throughout the island, particularly in the wet and intermediate zones.

Common English Name(s): Variegated Kukri Snake, Russell's Kukri Snake
A detailed description: A highly variable species. Typically light brown or greyish with dark brown or black crossbands that may be complete, broken, or reduced to spots. Some individuals may be almost patternless. The head usually has arrowhead markings.
how to find(recognize): Distinguished from O. arnensis by its more variable, often less defined, banding. It is a terrestrial snake found primarily in the dry and arid zones, often in scrubland and open country.
foods they eat: Feeds on reptile and bird eggs, lizards, and insects.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the low country dry zone, especially in the north and east.

Venom & Medical Significance: Non-venomous, Harmless. A large and powerful snake that will bite fiercely if cornered, but the bite is not medically significant.
A detailed description: fast-moving snake
how to find(recognize): often exceeding 2 meters. Coloration is variable
foods they eat: typically olive-green
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: yellowish

Venom & Medical Significance: Mildly venomous (rear-fanged). Has Duvernoy's glands. Venom can cause coagulation problems, but bites to humans are extremely rare and no severe envenomations are on record from Sri Lanka.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A medium-sized snake with a stout body and heavily keeled scales. The body is bright leaf-green or olive-green above
A detailed description: sometimes with faint black markings. The belly is whitish or yellowish. It has a distinct 'V' shaped mark on its neck."
how to find(recognize): Identified by its uniform green color, very rough (keeled) scales, and stout build. It is a terrestrial, diurnal snake, often found in damp areas like marshes, paddy fields, and forests, usually on the ground.
foods they eat: Feeds almost exclusively on toads. It is resistant to the toxins in toad skin.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found throughout the island, especially in the wet and intermediate zones.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): කලු හිස් දාර කරවලා (Kalu His Daara Karawala)
A detailed description: A small, slender snake. The body is light brown or reddish-brown with a dark vertebral line and a series of small black spots along the flanks. The head and neck are distinctively black or dark brown, followed by a bright yellow or orange collar. The belly is yellow.
how to find(recognize): Easily recognized by the combination of a black cap, a bright yellow/orange collar, and a thin, brown body. It is a secretive, diurnal, ground-dwelling snake found in the leaf litter of forests.
foods they eat: Feeds on small lizards, skinks, and other small snakes.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in the low country dry and intermediate zones.

A detailed description: This species is endemic to the Western Ghats of India and is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
how to find(recognize): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
foods they eat: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Contagion (Reproduction): This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: This species is not recorded from Sri Lanka.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): තෙල් කරවලා (Thel Karawala), මගමරුවා (Magamaruwa) / Kattu Viriyan (கட்டுவிரியன்)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic). Potentially lethal. Venom causes progressive paralysis, leading to respiratory failure. A bite is a major medical emergency, often occurring at night with minimal pain, leading to delayed treatment. Antivenom is available and essential.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A medium-sized snake with a glossy black or bluish-black body
A detailed description: encircled by 40-50 narrow
how to find(recognize): single white crossbands. The bands may be faint or absent on the anterior part of the body. The belly is white. A key feature is the row of enlarged hexagonal scales along the spine."
foods they eat: Identified by its glossy black color, single white bands, and the row of hexagonal vertebral scales. Often confused with the harmless Common Wolf Snake, which lacks the hexagonal scales. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial snake. During the day it hides in termite mounds, brick piles, and rodent burrows.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds primarily on other snakes, but also eats rodents, lizards, and frogs. It is cannibalistic.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying).

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): දුනු කරවලා (Dunu Karawala), මුදු කරවලා (Mudu Karawala)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic). Potentially lethal. Venom is similar to the Common Krait, causing paralysis and respiratory failure. A bite is a major medical emergency. Antivenom (Indian polyvalent) may have some efficacy but is less specific.
Global IUCN Red List Status: VU (Vulnerable),A medium-sized krait. The body is glossy black with 15-25 broad
A detailed description: white crossbands. Unlike the Common Krait
how to find(recognize): the bands are wider
foods they eat: fewer in number
Contagion (Reproduction): and are prominent from head to tail. It also has the enlarged hexagonal vertebral scales."
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Distinguished from the Common Krait by its fewer, much broader white bands. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial snake primarily found in the leaf litter of wet zone forests and hilly regions.

Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous (Neurotoxic). Bites are very rare due to its small size and secretive nature. While related to cobras and kraits, no deaths are recorded, but a bite should be treated with caution. Its medical significance is considered minor.
A detailed description: slender snake with a cylindrical body. The body is light brown or reddish-brown above
how to find(recognize): with a faint darker vertebral line. The head and neck are black
foods they eat: followed by a yellow or orange ring. The most striking feature is the tail
Contagion (Reproduction): which has a black ring and a bright red or orange underside
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: which it displays when threatened."

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic and Cytotoxic). Potentially lethal. Venom causes paralysis, respiratory failure, and severe local tissue damage (necrosis). A bite is a major medical emergency. Antivenom is available and essential.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A medium to large snake
A detailed description: famous for its ability to spread a hood. Coloration is variable
how to find(recognize): from yellowish-brown and grey to dark brown or black. The key feature is the 'spectacle' or monocle mark on the back of the hood
foods they eat: although this can sometimes be absent."
Contagion (Reproduction): Unmistakable when it spreads its hood, which it does when threatened. It is a terrestrial snake, active by day and night. Found in a very wide range of habitats, including forests, paddy fields, plantations, and even urban areas.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds mainly on rodents, but also on frogs, birds, and other snakes.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): තිත් පොළඟා (Thith Polanga) / Kannadi Viriyan (கண்ணாடி விரியன்)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Hemotoxic, Cytotoxic). Potentially lethal. Venom causes severe pain, swelling, blood clotting disorders (leading to hemorrhage), and kidney failure. A bite is a major medical emergency. Antivenom is available and essential.
A detailed description: very stout-bodied viper with a flattened
how to find(recognize): triangular head that is distinct from the neck. The body is light brown or yellowish-brown
foods they eat: with three longitudinal rows of large
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: circular blotches

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): වැලි පොළඟා (Weli Polanga) / Surattai Pambu (சுருட்டை பாம்பு)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Hemotoxic). Potentially lethal. Venom is a powerful hemotoxin causing systemic bleeding and coagulation problems. A bite is a major medical emergency. Antivenom is available and essential.
A detailed description: usually under 50 cm. The body is brownish
how to find(recognize): grayish
foods they eat: or sandy in color
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: dark-edged blotches along the back

Common English Name(s): Hump-nosed Pit Viper, Merrem's Hump-nosed Viper
Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous (Hemotoxic, Cytotoxic). Previously considered moderately venomous, it is now known to cause serious effects including pain, swelling, blood clotting issues, and acute kidney failure. No specific antivenom exists, making bites medically significant and potentially fatal.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A small pit viper with a stout body and a distinctly upturned snout. Coloration is grayish-brown with a double row of large
A detailed description: dark
how to find(recognize): subtriangular blotches on the back. The head is triangular. It has a heat-sensing pit between the eye and nostril."
foods they eat: Identified by its upturned snout ('hump-nose'). It is a nocturnal, terrestrial snake, very common in leaf litter in forests, plantations (rubber, tea, coconut), and home gardens. It is slow-moving and relies on camouflage.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on lizards, frogs, skinks, and small rodents.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young).

Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous. Assumed to be medically significant, similar to other Hypnale species.
Global IUCN Red List Status: NE (Not Evaluated),Very similar to H. hypnale. Differentiated by subtle characteristics like a more pointed snout
A detailed description: higher number of ventral scales
how to find(recognize): and specific details of its hemipenis structure. Identification is difficult without expert examination."
foods they eat: Difficult to distinguish from H. hypnale in the field. It is a nocturnal, terrestrial pit viper found in leaf litter in forested habitats.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on small vertebrates like frogs, lizards, and rodents.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young).

Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous. Assumed to be medically significant, similar to other Hypnale species.
A detailed description: with an upturned snout. Body color is darker brown or reddish-brown
how to find(recognize): often with less distinct dorsal blotches compared to H. hypnale. It is generally found at higher elevations."
foods they eat: Distinguished from H. hypnale by its darker coloration and higher altitude habitat. A nocturnal, terrestrial snake found in leaf litter in montane and sub-montane forests.
Contagion (Reproduction): Feeds on frogs, lizards, and shrews.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young).

Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous. Assumed to be medically significant, similar to other Hypnale species.
Global IUCN Red List Status: EN (Endangered),A small Hypnale species with a less prominently upturned snout. It is distinguished by its low number of ventral scales and specific color patterns
A detailed description: often having a more intricate head pattern."
how to find(recognize): Very difficult to identify without expert examination. A rare, nocturnal, ground-dwelling snake found in the leaf litter of specific lowland rainforest patches.
foods they eat: Feeds on small frogs and lizards.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Restricted to the lowland wet zone, particularly in the Ratnapura and Galle districts.

Common English Name(s): Sri Lankan Green Pit Viper, Pala Polanga
Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): පළා පොළඟා (Pala Polanga) / Kopi Viriyan (கோப்பி விரியன்)
Venom & Medical Significance: Venomous (Hemotoxic). Bites are common but rarely fatal. Venom causes severe local pain, swelling, and blood coagulation problems. Medical attention is required. No specific antivenom is available.
A detailed description: prehensile-tailed pit viper. Males are typically bright leaf-green with a blue and white or yellow and black stripe along the flank. Females are a more uniform green and larger. The head is broad
how to find(recognize): triangular
foods they eat: and distinct from the neck."
Contagion (Reproduction): Unmistakable due to its bright green color, triangular head, and prehensile tail. It is a nocturnal, arboreal snake, found in trees and shrubs in all forested areas of the wet and intermediate zones.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds on frogs, lizards, small birds, and rodents.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. It is a very aggressive snake with a potent venom. Bites are a major medical emergency. No specific antivenom for sea snakes is available in Sri Lanka.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A common sea snake with a greyish body
A detailed description: darker above and paler below
how to find(recognize): often with faint crossbands. The key feature is the downward-pointing
foods they eat: hook-like projection on its snout. The tail is flattened like a paddle for swimming."
Contagion (Reproduction): Identified by its hooked snout and marine habitat. It is found in shallow coastal waters, estuaries, and river mouths. Often encountered by fishermen.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds on fish, particularly catfish.

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): කහ බඩැති මුහුදු නයා (Kaha Badathi Mudu Naya)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. Despite its potent venom, it is generally not aggressive and bites are rare. However, any bite should be treated as a medical emergency.
A detailed description: unmistakable in its habitat. The dorsal side is uniform black or dark brown
how to find(recognize): sharply demarcated from a bright yellow or brownish belly. The tail is flattened and spotted with black."
foods they eat: The only pelagic (open ocean) snake. Recognized by its distinct bicolor pattern (dark top, bright yellow bottom). It is often found in large slicks or aggregations on the surface of the open ocean.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),The longest species of sea snake. The body is yellowish or yellowish-green with narrow black rings encircling the body. The head is yellow with black markings. The tail is flattened."
A detailed description: Recognized by its large size and pattern of black rings on a yellow background. Found in coastal waters.
how to find(recognize): Feeds on fish, especially eels.
foods they eat: Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Contagion (Reproduction): Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A very large and stout-bodied sea snake
A detailed description: possibly the heaviest of all. Coloration is variable
how to find(recognize): from cream or yellow to brown
foods they eat: with broad
Contagion (Reproduction): dark crossbands or blotches. It has a distinctive spine on the ventral scales
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: giving the belly a thorny feel."

Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): නිල් වළලු මුහුදු නයා (Nil Walalu Mudu Naya)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
A detailed description: slender sea snake. The body is yellowish or olive with dark bluish-black or black crossbands that are wider on the back and taper towards the belly."
how to find(recognize): Recognized by its pattern of dark, wide bands on a lighter background. Found in shallow coastal waters and estuaries.
foods they eat: Feeds on fish, especially eels.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A uniquely shaped sea snake. It has a very long
A detailed description: slender neck and anterior body
how to find(recognize): which then becomes much thicker towards the rear. Color is greyish above and whitish below
foods they eat: with dark bands or blotches."
Contagion (Reproduction): Identified by its disproportionately thin neck and front body compared to its thick rear body. Found in coastal waters.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Feeds on fish, using its thin neck to probe into burrows.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A stout-bodied sea snake. The body is light-colored (whitish to olive) with dark crossbands that are wider on the back. The head is large."
A detailed description: A common but variably patterned sea snake found in shallow marine environments.
how to find(recognize): Feeds on bottom-dwelling fish.
foods they eat: Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Contagion (Reproduction): Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A small sea snake with a short head and slender body. The body is yellowish or whitish with a series of dark
A detailed description: rhombus-shaped blotches along the back."
how to find(recognize): Identified by the series of dark diamond-shaped markings on its back. Found in coastal waters and estuaries.
foods they eat: Feeds on fish.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A medium-sized sea snake. Coloration is olive or yellowish with dark crossbands that are much wider on the back."
A detailed description: A common species in the coastal waters of the Indian Ocean.
how to find(recognize): Feeds on fish.
foods they eat: Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Contagion (Reproduction): Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A sea snake with olive or greyish coloration above and yellowish-white below
A detailed description: with dark bands encircling the body."
how to find(recognize): Difficult to distinguish from other banded sea snakes without close examination. Found in coastal waters.
foods they eat: Feeds on fish.
Contagion (Reproduction): Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Found in coastal waters around Sri Lanka.

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic, Myotoxic). Potentially lethal. A bite is a medical emergency.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),A sea snake with a large head
A detailed description: resembling a viper. The body is greyish above and whitish below
how to find(recognize): sometimes with dark crossbands or spots."
foods they eat: Named for its viper-like head. Found in coastal marine habitats.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Viviparous (gives birth to live young in the water).

Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic). Potentially lethal. However, it is a very placid and non-aggressive snake, and bites are extremely rare. It is amphibious, meaning it comes ashore.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),An amphibious sea snake (a sea krait). The body is cylindrical (not as flattened as true sea snakes) and patterned with distinct black bands on a bluish-grey background. The key feature is the bright yellow coloration on the snout and upper lip."
A detailed description: Recognized by the black and blue/grey banding and the distinct yellow snout. Unlike true sea snakes, it is often seen on land, on rocky shores and coral islands, where it rests, digests, and lays eggs.
how to find(recognize): Feeds almost exclusively on eels, which it hunts in coral reefs.
foods they eat: Oviparous (egg-laying). It is unique among sea snakes in Sri Lanka for laying its eggs on land, in rock crevices.
Contagion (Reproduction): Found on rocky coastlines and offshore islands, particularly in the south.

Common English Name(s): Common Sea Krait, Black-lipped Sea Krait
Local Name(s) (Sinhala/Tamil): කලු වැම්පත් මුහුදු නයා (Kalu Wampath Mudu Naya)
Venom & Medical Significance: Highly Venomous (Neurotoxic). Potentially lethal. Similar to L. colubrina, it is extremely docile and bites are virtually unheard of.
Global IUCN Red List Status: LC (Least Concern),Very similar to the Yellow-lipped Sea Krait
A detailed description: with a banded black and blue/grey body. The main difference is that the snout and upper lip are dark (black or dark brown)
how to find(recognize): not yellow."
foods they eat: Distinguished from L. colubrina by its dark, not yellow, snout. It shares the same amphibious habits, hunting in the sea and resting or laying eggs on land.
Areas spread across Sri Lanka: Oviparous (egg-laying) on land.
